attributes.title: Self-reported Cognitive, Physical, and Social factors of Anxious Freezing in Humans

q1.value: Self-reported Cognitive, Physical and Social Factors of Anxious Freezing in Humans:

q2.value: Maya Marder, Corey Richier, Wendy Heller

q3.value: While freezing behavior has been extensively explored in the animal literature, basic dimensions of human freeze remains relatively uncharted. Freezing, to date, has been conceptualized as an involuntary response to threatening stimuli, chiefly characterized by motor immobility and bradycardia (lowered heart rate). It has been understood in both animals and humans to appear predominantly under threat conditions that are perceived to be inescapable. Existing human research focuses primarily on self-reported, freeze-related response to severely traumatic events and subsequent behaviors that can be elicited in controlled, structured, experimental manner. As a result, there exists minimal empirical work demonstrating the cognitive markers, risk factors, manifestations or time course of human freezing behaviors in response to less severe emotional experiences. This study explores these concepts by presenting a newly developed Freezing questionnaire aimed at understanding the range of experiences that can elicit freezing behaviors in humans. Further exploration of individual risk factors that make one susceptible to such when enduring environmental threat will help expand beyond translational literature and guide future cognitive, neural and psychophysiological investigations of this concept.

q4.value:
Given the exploratory nature of this work, all of the following questions are to be explored after data collection is completed with thorough data analysis (see analysis plan):

Will "Anxious freezing" symptoms correlate highly with and load onto ruminative elements of anxious apprehension? 

Will freezing arise as a tertiary dimension of anxious organization (ie anxious arousal (panic), anxious apprehension (worry), and anxious freezing)? 

Will self-reported susceptibility to social evaluation be predictive of anxious freezing symptoms, regardless of previous traumatic experience?

Will self-reported physiological experience align with the literature - chiefly characterized by bradycardia?

Will self-reported cognitive function align with the literature - chiefly characterized by cognitive paralysis and heightened perception, simultaneously?

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
In order to explore this a priori expectation that unique experiences can invoke the expression of various physical and cognitive response, this study presents a newly created anxious freezing questionnaire designed to ask questions related to less severe anxiety-inducing events and the associated physical and cognitive responses. In conjunction with established self-report measures, we hope to locate freeze behaviors among understood definitions of anxiety through thorough analysis for systematic overlap, loading, and construct development. 

This exploratory, observational study consists of 11 different questionnaires to be completed in one sitting.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Although data collection has begun, no human analysis nor observation has occurred. Data collection completion is scheduled for May 2020.

question.value:
Participants will be comprised of a sample of undergraduate students (n=700) at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (UIUC). All questionnaires will be distributed to students of UIUC as part of a required element for an introductory psychology course via the SONA platform. Students will be compensated with commensurate course credit. All subjects must be 18 years or older to participate. No further exclusion is planned.
The demographic spread will ideally align with the ethnic composition of the Champaign-Urbana, IL population (according to the US Census conducted in 2018) in order to strengthen generalizable findings: 72% Caucasian, 13% Black or African American, 11% Asian, 6% Hispanic or Latino, 3% multiracial; 50% female. The research team acknowledges the binary measurement of gender put forth by such statistics. In our data collection, all endorsed gender identities will be included and acknowledged in subsequent analysis. Furthermore, the research team also acknowledges the limited nature of the college population and plans to extend beyond the bounds of the university in later confirmatory phases.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 500 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 700, but acknowledge that not all participants will fully complete the questionnaire.

q14.value: We utilized R to generate power analyses. In order to be sensitive to correlations at the .1 level at .8 power we would require a sample size of 782. However, given that we will be employing machine learning analyses (which will be described in more detail in the analytical section) there is less convention in power analyses. Our proposed analytical plan has shown to be effective with roughly 400 for a sample size. By convention for exploratory factor analysis, we will have enough power for roughly 5-6 participants for each item included in our anxious freezing measure.

question.value:
This thorough self-report questionnaire battery will consist of all questions included in the Anxiety Sensitivity Index (ASI; (Reiss & McNally, 1985; Reiss et al., 1986), Penn State Worry Questionnaire (PSWQ; Meyer et al., 1990), adapted Mood and Anxiety Symptom Questionnaire (MASQ; Watson et al., 2005), Social Interaction Anxiety Scale (SIAS; Mattick & Clark, 1989), Social Identities and Attitudes Scale (SIASii; Picho & Brown, 2011), Life Events Checklist (LEC; Weathers et al., 2013), Rumination-Reflection Questionnaire (RRQ; Trapnell and Campbell, 1999), Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function for Adults (BRIEF-A; Roth et al., 2005), Approach-Avoidance Temperament Questionnaire (ATQ; Elliot & Thrash, 2010), The Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS - Trait;. Watson et al., 1988), Anxious Freezing Questionnaire (AFQ; present study and research team).

All items will be proposed and scored as originally designed. The newly developed questionnaire to measure the cognitive, physical and social aspects of human freezing will be psychometrically tested after data completion.

Results will be analyzed through a hierarchical machine learning approach. Data will be topologically organized into dendrograms allowing for hierarchical clustering. This plan allows for loading, exploratory factor analysis, and psychometric validation analysis to be completed. All analysis will be completed in R.

In order to analyze the psychometric properties of the Anxious Freezing Questionnaire, we will use hierarchical clustering analyses in order to examine the topological structures of anxious freezing in comparison to anxious arousal and anxious apprehension. Machine learning strategies for psychometrics are an emerging strategy in the literature and the present study seeks to utilize them in an exploratory fashion to see if and how our hypothetical freezing dimension may arise out of our survey. Topological analyses of hierarchical clustering have been successfully applied to neuroimaging studies, neuropsychological testing, and pharmacological testing.  Patterns formulated in survey response data can be conceptualized in terms of geometric structures. The properties of connections between structures can be computed utilizing properties of homotopy and homology. Using filtration, which iteratively changes the perspective of data being examined can create nested sequences of features in the data as algebraic objects. This information can be reapplied in the creation of topological features in the data by going up/down a certain number of filtrations in the data. Hierarchical clustering analysis, which is a machine learning algorithm that can group like objects into categorically similar arrangements, can be applied to the topological filtrations created in this process. The patterns in the data can be visualized using dendrograms, or topological mappings in the geometry of survey items. Due to the fact they have defined geometric space, they can be similarly analyzed using geometric analytical techniques. We will employ the Hausdorff metric, which measures the distance between two objects objects in the same dimension. Two sets are considered proximal if every point of one set is close to another point in the other set. The greatest distance between close points can generate a nearness metric on two objects (comparing topological structures.) It is then possible to calculate distance based nonparametric tests about the structure of the dendrograms. 

This analytical procedure will be carried out using the pvclust package in R. Code utilized for the project will be posted as well. Concrete analytical steps are as follows:

1. Partition master sample into training and validation samples from the data (75-25% split)
2. Generate bootstrap samples from dataset
3. Calculate distance metrics across training and validation samples
4. Utilize single-linkage hierarchical clustering on the training sample for exploratory analysis of questionnaire structure
5. Test internal consistency (using chronbach's alpha) on training sample 
6. Create heat maps and dendrograms of training sample 
7. Repeat steps 4-7 on validation sample
8. Utilize Hausdorff distance metrics to examine differences in dendrograms between training and sample datasets
9. Utilize NHST against various permutations of the dendrograms (or through generation of random dendrograms utilizing cross-validation) to obtain p values
10. Utilize Bonferroni correction for dendrogram NHST. If p value is below .05, no statistically significant differences exist in the structure of dendrograms, meaning hierarchical clusters in data are consistent and valid

We also will utilize traditional exploratory and confirmatory factor analytic approaches to examine the dimensions of freezing. We may consider designing a comparative design study of the hierarchical clustering vs. the EFA/CFA methodologies on our variables of interest to better compare and contrast machine learning methodologies against the existing standard for psychometric validation in clinical psychological science.

q20.value: Survey data will be mean centered.

q21.value: P values for the NHST of dendrogram structure will be set at .05

q22.value: We will verify that respondents completed the surveys in full to be included. Our data collection platform, REDCap, was programmed to force item completion so in theory little missing data should exist.

q23.value: Procedures for excluding missing data to be generated.

q24.value: We may consider utilizing unsupervised machine learning techniques to examine patterns in survey response. Additionally, we may pursue further machine learning based analyses to examine the relationship between anxious freezing to other anxiety dimensions.

attributes.title: Pseudocontingencies vs Denominator Neglect
attributes.description: Manipulation of rewards/no rewards in induction phase as manipulation for PCs vs Denom. effect

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value:
The sample size was estimated to be around Ni = 100 per cell, or N = 200 total, based on power analyses using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007). These calculations are based on a 5% alpha-level, 85% statistical power, and effect sizes around d = .3 as reported by Harris, Fiedler, Marien, and Custers (2020) and Harris, Fiedler, and Custers (2020).

Harris, C., Fiedler, K., Marien, H., Custers, R. (2020). Biased preferences through exploitation: How initial biases are consolidated in reward-rich environments. Journal of Experimental Psychology: General.
Harris, C., Fiedler, K., Custers, R. (2020). When biases beget biases: Exploitation and the maintenance of erroneous action-outcome beliefs. Unpublished manuscript.

analyses.value: Across measures, we expect the two conditions to be biased away from chance level in opposite directions and test this with t-tests and the Bayesian equivalent.

dependent.value:
Relative preference: by having participants indicate their estimates on a slider.
Conditional estimates: by having participants indicate their estimates on a slider. 
Choice: by having participants indicate their choice in a repeated choice task over 84 trials.

conditions.value: Two. Participants either first encounter the initial evidence and only then learn which of two fruits earns or loses them points and which fruit they can ignore. Or they first learn the information about the fruit and then encounter the initial evidence.

hypothesis.value:
In this experiment participants will encounter a distribution of initial evidence that is doubly skewed: one of two options occurs more frequently and one of two outcomes occurs more frequently. More specifically, they will encounter either of two locations frequently and will encounter either a lot of grapes and few strawberries, or few strawberries and a lot of grapes. The fruit which occurs infrequent is always the one that earns or loses them points, while the other fruit does not earn them any points. Across trials, participants will therefore often lose points and less frequently earn points. Importantly, in one condition (DN) participants will know from the beginning on which fruit is of relevance and which fruit they can ignore. In the other condition (PC), they only learn this information after encountering the initial evidence. Based on this information, we expect participants to focus on different information and to form different biases.

In the DN condition, we expect participants to form inferences as described by the ratio bias (Denes-Raj, Epstein, and Cole, 1995). That is, we expect them to associate the frequent option with positive outcomes. Even while positive outcomes were seldom in general, participants still encountered more of them with the frequent option than with the infrequent option. By ignoring the baserates, denominator neglect-type inferences are a reasonable prediction.

In the PC condition, we expect participants to form Pseudocontingency-type inferences (Fiedler, Freytag, and Meiser, 2009). That is, we expect them to associate the frequent option with the frequent outcome (losing) and the infrequent option with the infrequent outcome (winning). Through baserate alignment participants would come to opposite conclusions than the DN condition.

Fiedler, K., Freytag, P., Meiser, T. (2009). Pseudocontingencies: an integrative account of an intriguing cognitive illusion. Psychological Review, 116(1), 187-206. doi:10.1037/a0014480
Denes-Raj, V., Epstein, S., Cole, J. (1995). The generality of the ratio-bias phenomenon. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 21(10), 1083-1092. doi:10.1177/01461672952110009

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Pseudocontingencies vs Denominator Neglect II

The sample size was estimated to be around Ni = 100 per cell, or N = 200 total, based on power analyses using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007). These calculations are based on a 5% alpha-level, 85% statistical power, and effect sizes around d = .3 as reported by Harris, Fiedler, Marien, and Custers (2020) and Harris, Fiedler, and Custers (2020).

Harris, C., Fiedler, K., Marien, H., Custers, R. (2020). Biased preferences through exploitation: How initial biases are consolidated in reward-rich environments. Journal of Experimental Psychology: General.
Harris, C., Fiedler, K., Custers, R. (2020). When biases beget biases: Exploitation and the maintenance of erroneous action-outcome beliefs. Unpublished manuscript.

registration_responses.conditions: Two. Participants either first encounter the initial evidence and only then learn which of two fruits earns or loses them points and which fruit they can ignore. Or they first learn the information about the fruit and then encounter the initial evidence.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
In this experiment participants will encounter a distribution of initial evidence that is doubly skewed: one of two options occurs more frequently and one of two outcomes occurs more frequently. More specifically, they will encounter either of two locations frequently and will encounter either a lot of grapes and few strawberries, or few strawberries and a lot of grapes. The fruit which occurs infrequent is always the one that earns or loses them points, while the other fruit does not earn them any points. Across trials, participants will therefore often lose points and less frequently earn points. Importantly, in one condition (DN) participants will know from the beginning on which fruit is of relevance and which fruit they can ignore. In the other condition (PC), they only learn this information after encountering the initial evidence. Based on this information, we expect participants to focus on different information and to form different biases.

In the DN condition, we expect participants to form inferences as described by the ratio bias (Denes-Raj, Epstein, and Cole, 1995). That is, we expect them to associate the frequent option with positive outcomes. Even while positive outcomes were seldom in general, participants still encountered more of them with the frequent option than with the infrequent option. By ignoring the baserates, denominator neglect-type inferences are a reasonable prediction.

In the PC condition, we expect participants to form Pseudocontingency-type inferences (Fiedler, Freytag, and Meiser, 2009). That is, we expect them to associate the frequent option with the frequent outcome (losing) and the infrequent option with the infrequent outcome (winning). Through baserate alignment participants would come to opposite conclusions than the DN condition.

Fiedler, K., Freytag, P., Meiser, T. (2009). Pseudocontingencies: an integrative account of an intriguing cognitive illusion. Psychological Review, 116(1), 187-206. doi:10.1037/a0014480
Denes-Raj, V., Epstein, S., Cole, J. (1995). The generality of the ratio-bias phenomenon. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 21(10), 1083-1092. doi:10.1177/01461672952110009

q1.value: Merit & Privilege: Advantage vs. Disadvantage Framing, Version 2

q2.value: Stephanie Tepper, Rachel King, Amy Krosch

q3.value: Our research thus far finds that acknowledging the role of privilege in an accomplishment threatens perceptions of merit or deservingness. In this study, we seek to test whether reframing White privilege as a lack of disadvantage based on race (vs. as an advantage based on race) might make it easier for people to acknowledge the role of privilege in their accomplishments.

q4.value: Our central hypothesis is that participants who see privilege framed as a lack of disadvantage will be more likely to acknowledge their privilege than those who see it framed as an advantage (or simply see it labeled explicitly as privilege). We also hypothesize that these participants will see privilege as less of a threat to merit. However, given previous results, we do not have any directional hypotheses about how this will influence their actual ratings of merit.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study employs a three-group, between-subjects design.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three between-subjects conditions using the Qualtrics block randomization feature.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via Prolific Academic. We will compensate participants $0.48 for their participation in this 3-minute survey (a rate of $9.60/hour). We will restrict our sample to White participants living in the United States.

q13.value: We will collect responses from 450 participants.

q14.value: We conducted a power analysis using G*Power. A sample size of 450 participants will enable us to detect a small-to-medium Cohen's f of .17 at 90% power.

q15.value: Aside from occasional errors with online data collection (in which more or fewer people participate than requested), we will have full control over our sample size.

question.value:
After describing an accomplishment, participants will be assigned to one of three framing conditions to rate the role of privilege in their accomplishment:

1. Privilege (control) condition: "Certain racial identities benefit from having privilege in society. To what extent do you agree that this privilege played a role in the accomplishment you described?"
2. Advantage condition: "Certain racial identities benefit from having more advantages in society. To what extent do you agree that this advantage played a role in the accomplishment you described?"
3. Disadvantage condition: "Certain racial identities benefit from having fewer disadvantages in society. To what extent do you agree that this lack of disadvantage played a role in the accomplishment you described?"

Participants will write about an accomplishment in their lives. Participants will then rate the role of privilege (with the accompanying framing manipulation for each condition). Participants will rate the role of merit in their accomplishments as well. Finally, participants will rate the extent to which they believe that acknowledging their privilege (defined to match the framing conditions) threatens their merit. See attached for the full survey.
N/A

1. We will conduct an ANOVA and pairwise contrasts to compare ratings of privilege between conditions. 
2. We will conduct an ANOVA and pairwise contrasts to compare ratings of merit between conditions. 
3. We will conduct an ANOVA and pairwise contrasts to compare ratings of the extent to which acknowledging privilege threatens merit between conditions.

q21.value: We will use a standard alpha of .05 to make inferences.

q22.value: If participants indicate that they will not provide quality responses, or if they indicate that they have taken a similar survey on Amazon Mechanical Turk, we will exclude their data from the analyses.

q23.value: If any items for measures that will be included in the analyses are missing, the corresponding cases will be removed from the analyses.

Participants will then rate the role of privilege (with the accompanying framing manipulation for each condition). Participants will rate the role of merit in their accomplishments as well. Finally, participants will rate the extent to which they believe that acknowledging their privilege (defined to match the framing conditions) threatens their merit. See attached for the full survey.
registration_responses.q18.question: N/A
registration_responses.q19.question:
1. We will conduct an ANOVA and pairwise contrasts to compare ratings of privilege between conditions. 
2. We will conduct an ANOVA and pairwise contrasts to compare ratings of merit between conditions. 
3. We will conduct an ANOVA and pairwise contrasts to compare ratings of the extent to which acknowledging privilege threatens merit between conditions.

summary.value:
Memories from experience: Bad outcomes are wrongly recognized more than good


In a previous pre-registration (1-1-2020, https://osf.io/ksyg3) we hypothesized that losses, compared with gains, will lead to more false-alarms. We based these predictions on the literature suggesting increased attention to losses, and on three lab studies we ran before.
In the new study, we made some few changes to the recognition task to address shortcomings of the previous studies.
We did not find the predicted effect in the results, but found a significant increase in misses for losses. That is, participants tended to “forget” the negative stimuli they experienced.
However, there is a major fundamental difference between the new and old recognition tasks we used. In the previous one, we presented participants with a list of stimuli (positive and negative), some of them are old and some are new (lures), and asked them to mark the ones they encountered. In the new task they were presented with the un-signed stimuli (both new and old), and asked to mark each one if they recognize it as positive, negative, or don’t recognize (new). Thus, the new recognition task is more of a categorization task.
Another difference is the number of lures added to the recognition task: 12 in the previous tasks and 8 in the new one. Participants could use the number of items to recognize (20 versus 16) as a cue to the number of old stimuli. In other words, the number of stimuli in the recognition task affects the number of “old” selections, leading to decreased misses and increased false-alarms with more “new” stimuli. Note that it does not explain the valence effects found in both tasks.

In the present proposal we suggest to formally evaluate the effects of number of lures and type of recognition task on misses and false-alarms, in a between-subject, 2x2 (recognition-task x number of lures) design. 

-	The tasks and design for each condition are the ones described in the pre-registration #1.
-	We will not run the Anagrams condition.
-	We aim to run 400 participants (100 per condition).
-	The study will run online in mTurk as before.
-	We will use ANOVA and post-hoc comparisons (on false-alarms and misses) to analyze the data.

registration_responses.summary:
Memories from experience: Bad outcomes are wrongly recognized more than good


In a previous pre-registration (1-1-2020, https://osf.io/ksyg3) we hypothesized that losses, compared with gains, will lead to more false-alarms. We based these predictions on the literature suggesting increased attention to losses, and on three lab studies we ran before.
In the new study, we made some few changes to the recognition task to address shortcomings of the previous studies.
We did not find the predicted effect in the results, but found a significant increase in misses for losses. That is, participants tended to “forget” the negative stimuli they experienced.
However, there is a major fundamental difference between the new and old recognition tasks we used. In the previous one, we presented participants with a list of stimuli (positive and negative), some of them are old and some are new (lures), and asked them to mark the ones they encountered. In the new task they were presented with the un-signed stimuli (both new and old), and asked to mark each one if they recognize it as positive, negative, or don’t recognize (new). Thus, the new recognition task is more of a categorization task.
Another difference is the number of lures added to the recognition task: 12 in the previous tasks and 8 in the new one. Participants could use the number of items to recognize (20 versus 16) as a cue to the number of old stimuli. In other words, the number of stimuli in the recognition task affects the number of “old” selections, leading to decreased misses and increased false-alarms with more “new” stimuli. Note that it does not explain the valence effects found in both tasks.

In the present proposal we suggest to formally evaluate the effects of number of lures and type of recognition task on misses and false-alarms, in a between-subject, 2x2 (recognition-task x number of lures) design. 

-	The tasks and design for each condition are the ones described in the pre-registration #1.
-	We will not run the Anagrams condition.
-	We aim to run 400 participants (100 per condition).
-	The study will run online in mTurk as before.
-	We will use ANOVA and post-hoc comparisons (on false-alarms and misses) to analyze the data.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: In this paper, we unpack the definition and measurement of violence and nonviolence contentious action in empirical research. We propose a conceptualization of violent and nonviolent action which accounts for the (1) threat of immediate harm, and (2) bearing of arms by contentious actors. Additionally, we consider the role of identity in shaping the classification of violence and nonviolence. Drawing on a recent focus in the terrorism literature, we consider how the out-group status of a contentious actor may consciously or unconsciously shift the classification of that individual's action to be more violent. We conduct two survey experiments - one in the Israel and one in the United States. We present respondents with a news article describing a contentious action in their country. Respondents are randomly exposed to one of four possible actions and three possible identities of the contentious actors. Respondents classify the action as violent or nonviolent, and rate their approval with the response of the police to the action.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1: Contentious political actions which threaten immediate harm are more likely to be classified as violent and justify a repressive state response than contentious actions which do not threaten immediate harm. Hypothesis 2: Contentious political actions which involve the use of arms are more likely to be classified as violent and justify a repressive state response than contentious actions which do not involve the use of arms. Hypothesis 3: Contentious political actions perpetrated by an out-group member are more likely to be classified as violent and justify a repressive state response than contentious actions perpetrated by an in- group member. Hypothesis 3b: Contentious political actions perpetrated by an out-group member are more likely to be classified as violent and justify a repressive state response if the actions occur more proximate to the observer. We estimate the hypotheses in two different ways. First, we use a simple difference in means with standard errors calculated through randomization inference to test Hypotheses 1 and 2. That is, we take the expected difference in classification of violence and justification for state force between those who receive the threatened and unthreatened conditions (for Hypothesis 1) and between those who receive the armed and unarmed conditions (for Hypothesis 2). Second, we separately regress classification of violence and justification of state force on a treatment indicator for the threatened condition (Hypothesis 1) and the armed condition (Hypothesis 2). Each of these procedures produces an unbiased estimate of the same causal quantity: the average treatment effect (ATE). Testing Hypothesis 3 varies based on the survey experiment. In the Israeli survey experiment, we replicate the same procedures used to estimate the ATE for the Hypotheses 1 and 2. We take the expected difference in the classification of violence and justification for state force between those who receive the out-group (Hamas) and in-group (Israeli settlers) conditions. We also separately regress those outcome measures on a treatment indicator for out-group status. Hypothesis 3b is also tested in the Israeli case through estimating the (non-causal) conditional average treatment effect (CATE) of the out-group treatment based on respondents' location. The CATE is estimated through a regression of the outcome measures on an interaction between the out-group treatment indicator and a respondent's proximity to the Gaza Strip, which is governed by Hamas and where Hamas contentious actions occur. In the American survey experiment, we do not have a causal manipulation for out-group status since such status depends on the partisan identification of the respondent. We instead estimate the CATE by interacting the left-wing/right-wing treatment with the partisan identification of the respondent.

q17.value: We test our hypotheses about the classification of violence with two survey experiments implemented on Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk). Our sample consists of an estimated 2000 respondents from Amazon Mechanical Turk's online task platform, 1000 from Israel and 1000 from the United States. The survey will be designed through Qualtrics software and uploaded to Mechanical Turk. Respondents will be compensated based on the amount of time spent for completion of the survey at a rate of $0.10 a minute, which is above the median level of compensation for Mechanical Turk's Human Intelligence Tasks. Institutional Review Board guidelines generally require that respondents' compensation not be conditioned on completion of the task, which we follow in the implementation of this survey.

Respondents classify the action as violent or nonviolent, and rate their approval with the response of the police to the action.

attributes.title: Application of the Oregon CIR model in Switzerland

q1.value: Second panel wave testing long-term use of a citizens' summary statement and its effect on voters' decision-making in a Swiss federal initiative vote

q3.value:
The registered study contains an online survey of a second panel wave for Swiss voters in the municipality of Sion. After having manipulated different versions of a citizens' summary statement displayed to voters in a web survey prior to an upcoming Swiss federal initiative vote, this survey probes the voters' usage of the statement in addition to other voting cues they might have encountered in the meantime. 
The experiment contributes to past research on the external effects of Citizens' Jurys by investigating the usage of the summary statement.
 
Questions:
Have voters made use of the summary statement? Which other cues did they use to form an opinion on the topic of the initiative? How do voters evaluate the statement if they read it?

q4.value:
Voters who have already voted have a higher likelihood of having used multiple cues.
Voters who have already voted have a higher likelihood of having used the summary statement.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Second wave of a within-subject panel survey of interested individuals via email and letter who were initially random sampled and took part in a field experiment exploring the short-term and long-term effects of voters' decision-making. 
No experimental variation.

q9.value: No randomization involved in this study (consent-based repeated survey).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited using the following procedure:
1st step: Drawing a random sample of voter addresses from the voter registration database of the municipality of Sion.
2nd step: Removing neighbouring addresses and conducting additional measures to ensure non-interference between treatment and control groups as well as excludibility.
3rd step: Sending an online survey invitation by letter to previously sampled voters in the first wave who did not opt out for the second wave.
4th step: Collecting response data via the online web survey platform "SoSci Survey"

q13.value: Individual voters constitute the subjects of this study. Out target sample size is N=200.

q14.value: The rationale for this sample size is to have as many respondents from the first wave of the study. The first wave included ca. 900 complete responses.

question.value:
Outcome variables post-treatment:

- Eight 7-point scales measuring facilitative trust
  (1 ‘‘strongly disagree’’ to 7 ‘‘strongly agree"’)
- 5-point scale initiative support (definitely NO,Undecided, definitely Yes)
- 3-point modal scale vote intention (Yes, No, Undecided)
- 5-point scale likeliness of voting (Less likely to vote, Made no difference, more likely to vote)
Inclusion of further statement evaluation posttreatment variables (7-point scales  if not otherwise stated):
- Awareness: CIR/Statement (CIR also for control)
- Source of information on the CIR
- Helpfulness in deciding to vote (Made no difference, Somewhat helpful, Very helpful)
- Perceived importance
- Perceived novelty and quantity of novel information gained from the statement’s parts
- Usefulness Statement (Made no difference, Somewhat useful, Very useful)
- Informativeness
- Trust placed in the sections of the statement

Additional variables concerning the statement evaluation may be included in the final survey. 	

Socio-demographics post-treatment:
- Feeling close to a particular party and if yes which one (categorical; Y/N; party)

No further interest in participating in the third wave of the  within-subject panel survey (Yes, no further interest.).
Additive indices of facilitative trust (subindices with items of the competence dimension and the interest dimensions)

Estimation of ATEs with multiple regression models
Estimation of within-subject effects with FE or RE panel models
Mean-comparison tests (t-Tests, ANOVA)
Other descriptive statistics (correlations)
Principal Component Analysis

q21.value: In addition to the evaluation of the substantial size of effects within the sample, p-values smaller than .05 are used as a cut-off value for significance.

q23.value:
Handling of missing data
Using multipe imputation for missing values or, alternatively, EM-based imputation.

attributes.title: Final Paper
attributes.withdrawal_justification: I accidentally published this pre-reg. for a class assignment. It was not meant to be public. The original authors are Madeline Springle, Laura Tian, and Emily Schwartzman.
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

attributes.title: A Preference for Error-Inducing Price Complexity

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

other.value:
Any contrasts between aforementioned conditions but not mentioned as supporting hypotheses may be explored in secondary analyses.

Only 50 observations have been collected so far, because the PhD student running this study got approval for the preregistration at the same time she got approval for the study in general (email copy available), and then she forgot about it when running a soft launch. (The remaining 400 will be run after this registration.)

sample.value: 450 participants will be recruited via MTurk

analyses.value:
We will use proportions tests and logistic regressions with binary outcomes to identify:
1)The proportions of subjects who prefer the complex information display.  
2) The proportions of subjects who successfully choose the lowest-fee/ lowest-sum option in the choice task.
3) Whether any attitudinal measures are correlated with choices.

outliers.value:
We will exclude participants who do not answer key dependent variables. 
In robustness checks, we may also exclude participants who do not pass an attention check and/or whose location cannot be verified to be unique.

dependent.value:
Preference: Participants will indicate whether they prefer information displayed in a relatively complex (vs. simple) way. 

Choice in selection task: Whether or not participants successfully chose the option with the lower total.

Secondary: Perceptions of trustworthiness/ transparency in companies that display fees in more/ less detail, expectations of success in selecting lowest-fee options with different fee disclosures, confidence in having selected the lowest-fee option

conditions.value:
Format condition: Subjects will be randomly assigned to one of the following scenarios:
1)	Prepaid card condition: This condition will describe a product.
2)	Vague/ “Abstracted” fees condition: This condition will mimic the prepaid card condition in most ways, except subjects will be told they’re making a decision about a “product” and fees will be given abstract labels (e.g., “Fee 1, Fee 2,…). 
3)	Math condition: This condition will mimic the previous conditions in most ways, except subjects will be told they’re simply completing an “arithmetic test.” Instead of a fee disclosure, subjects will be presented a list of numbers to add up. 

Choice task: Subjects will be randomly assigned to complete an incentivized choice task (incentivized to pick the lowest sum total) either with two simple or with two complex options.

hypothesis.value:
H1: Subjects tasked with adding up numbers will be more likely to prefer a simple list of numbers than subjects tasked with adding up fees will prefer a simple fee disclosure. 
-We don’t have any strong predictions about the vague/ “abstracted” fees condition, but the proportion of subjects preferring a simple disclosure will probably fall between the other two conditions. 

H2a: Subjects with a higher need for cognition will prefer the more complex fee disclosures/ lists of numbers across all conditions.

H2b: Need for cognition will significantly moderate the impact of format condition on preferences, such that the relationship between need for cognition and a preference for complexity will be stronger in the math-only condition and less strong in the prepaid card condition. 
-Again, we don’t have any strong predictions about the vague/ “abstracted” fees condition, but the interaction effect with need for cognition will probably fall between the reference level and the interaction effect for the other condition.

(The remaining 400 will be run after this registration.)

3)	Math condition: This condition will mimic the previous conditions in most ways, except subjects will be told they’re simply completing an “arithmetic test.” Instead of a fee disclosure, subjects will be presented a list of numbers to add up.

attributes.title: Wisdom and Bullshit
attributes.description: Examining how reflecting on meaningless information can enhance meaning

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
We will measure "Liking of statement" for each statement to be used as a control variable in the analyses.
We will explore differences in perceived difficulty to reflect on the statements associated with admirable vs. not admirable public figures.
We will explore the overall credibility of the statements in the 2 speaker conditions.

sample.value:
We will run 300 participants (150 for each between groups condition), to match the sample size from our first study.
The sample will be collected using turkprime.

analyses.value:
Wise reflection: We will estimate a MLM with participants as a random factor, trial as a random factor, type of statement as a within-groups predictor and type of speaker as a between-groups predictor.
Meaning-seeking: We will estimate a MLM with participants as a random factor, trial as a random factor, type of statement as a within-groups predictor and type of speaker as a between-groups predictor.
SWIS: We will estimate a MLM with participants as a random factor, trial as a random factor, type of statement as a within-groups predictor and type of speaker as a between-groups predictor.

outliers.value:
We will exclude:
1. Responses coming from duplicate IPs and duplicate Mturk worker IDs.
2. Participants who do not complete the experimental trials or DVs
3. Participants who fail a final attention check of listing 2 (out of 4) of the famous speakers presented during the experiment.
4. Participants who did not write anything or wrote nonsense (e.g., "good") in open-ended segments.
5. Participants who stated that at least 2 out of 4 statements do not belong to the speaker

dependent.value:
1. Open ended reflection following each of 4 statements (2 meaningless, 2 inspirational) coded by coders (blind to the experimental conditions) for wise reasoning (i.e., considering others' perspectives, intellectual humility, taking a distant viewpoint) and meaning-seeking.
2. State sense of meaning- We will use the MLQ purpose subscale (Steger et al., 2006). Specifically, we will use 3 items modified to assess the meaning of statements:
   1. I understand the statements’ meaning.
   2. I have a good sense of what makes the statements meaningful.
   3. The statements have no clear purpose (reverse coded)
3. SWIS scale (Brienza Kung, Santos, Bobocel, & Grossmann, 2017) adapted for the current study.
4. Profundity ratings per statement.

conditions.value:
Within groups- type of statement - meaningless vs. inspirational statement
Between groups- type of speaker- admirable vs. not admirable

hypothesis.value: We test whether reflecting on meaningless information enhances a general sense of meaning and wiser reasoning when this information is associated with an admirable (vs. less admirable) public figure.

5. Participants who stated that at least 2 out of 4 statements do not belong to the speaker
registration_responses.dependent:
1. Open ended reflection following each of 4 statements (2 meaningless, 2 inspirational) coded by coders (blind to the experimental conditions) for wise reasoning (i.e., considering others' perspectives, intellectual humility, taking a distant viewpoint) and meaning-seeking.
2. State sense of meaning- We will use the MLQ purpose subscale (Steger et al., 2006). Specifically, we will use 3 items modified to assess the meaning of statements:
   1. I understand the statements’ meaning.
   2. I have a good sense of what makes the statements meaningful.
   3. The statements have no clear purpose (reverse coded)
3. SWIS scale (Brienza Kung, Santos, Bobocel, & Grossmann, 2017) adapted for the current study.
4. Profundity ratings per statement.
registration_responses.conditions:
Within groups- type of statement - meaningless vs. inspirational statement
Between groups- type of speaker- admirable vs. not admirable
registration_responses.hypothesis: We test whether reflecting on meaningless information enhances a general sense of meaning and wiser reasoning when this information is associated with an admirable (vs. less admirable) public figure.

attributes.title: Memory for Rapidly Presented Food Images

q1.value: Free Recall for Rapidly Presented Food Images

q3.value: There is abundant evidence of attentional biases to food versus nonfood images and potentially even high energy versus low energy food images. We believe similar biases exist to the human memory system, and that these mnemonic biases may reflect evolutionary pressures. While we have acquired some evidence of this using a recognition memory task, we now seek to find a similar bias using free recall.

q4.value: We predict better recall memory for high energy food images compared to low energy or nonfood images. We also predict individuals with higher BMI to display a larger bias towards remembering high energy food images.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study utilizes a within-subjects design, with each subject being presented with high energy food, low energy food, and nonfood images. The study will be correlational in analyzing BMI and memory performance associations.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will complete the study for course credit and will be recruited through UCLA's SONA system. Studies will be conducted in individual cubicles in psychology laboratories at UCLA.

q14.value: The sample size reflects a power analysis to detect a medium effect (f = .25) with 90% power, using our study design.

question.value: We will manipulate the type of image presented. Images will either be of high energy food (greater than 300 kcal per 100 grams), low energy food (fewer than 100 kcal per 100 grams), or nonfood images. Images are taken from the food-pics database and will be equivalent on a variety of factors such as, color (red, blue green) composition, object size, intensity, contrast, complexity, spatial frequency, desirability, number of items, recognizability, valence, and total weight.

Participants will have five minutes to complete a free-recall task using a pen and paper. Participants will be instructed to provide simple descriptions of each item they remember seeing. Two independent reviewers will then score the recall descriptions and attempt to match each description to the 30 images presented. A 3rd independent reviewer will settle any inconsistencies between reviewers. Only images with at least 2/3 agreement will be considered correct.  We will also measure participant BMI and anticipate those with higher BMI to show a stronger bias towards remembering high energy food images and to show greater desire to eat high energy food images. We will also have participants rate all food images on how much they desire to eat them. Based on the food-pics database, we predict there to be no difference in desirability of the high energy versus low energy food images. If there are differences, we predict more desired food images to be better remembered than low desired food images.

We will use a repeated measures ANOVA with one within subject factor (image type) to analyze these results. If we find a significant effect of image type, we will conduct planned comparisons between high energy vs. low energy images, high energy vs nonfood images, and low energy vs nonfood images. 

We will run a Pearson's r correlation between BMI and high energy food bias (high energy food retention - low energy food retention per subject).

While we have acquired some evidence of this using a recognition memory task, we now seek to find a similar bias using free recall.
